content: The Act may be cited as the "Vessel Discharge Evaluation and Review Act". Key findings are also included in the Act. The United States Coast Guard has been the main authority for regulating pollutant discharge from vessels since 1980. There are millions of boats and vessels operating in US waters, with certain discharges exempted from regulation since 1973. Congress has mandated Federal programs for controlling vessel discharges when necessary. The United States Coast Guard has regulated pollutant discharge from vessels since 1980, with Federal programs established to control discharges. Legislation including the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships in 1980, the Nonindigenous Aquatic Nuisance Prevention and Control Act of 1990, the National Invasive Species Act of 1996, and section 1401 of the 2000 Omnibus Consolidated and Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Fiscal Year 2001 have been enacted to prevent specific types of discharges. SEC. 3. Evaluation and review of certain discharges. The Commandant of the Coast Guard, in consultation with other agencies, shall conduct an evaluation and review of vessel discharges, excluding aquatic nuisance species. This includes characterizing types and volumes of discharges, analyzing technologies and costs for controlling discharges. The Commandant of the Coast Guard, in consultation with other agencies, will evaluate and review vessel discharges, excluding aquatic nuisance species. This will involve analyzing the types, locations, and potential effects of discharges on human health and the environment, as well as identifying measures to control them. Additionally, recommendations for regulatory changes and implementation schedules will be provided. Public comments on a draft report containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations will be published. The Commandant of the Coast Guard will prepare a final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations from the evaluation and review of vessel discharges. The report will be submitted to the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the House of Representatives Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure within 2 years of the enactment of the Act. Public comments on the draft report will be accepted for at least 120 days before the final report is prepared. SEC. 4 of the Act focuses on establishing environmentally sound standards for discharges from vessels and creating procedures for designating no discharge zones to protect state waters. Additionally, the Act amends the Nonindigenous Aquatic Nuisance Prevention and Control Act to regulate certain discharges. The Vessel Discharge Evaluation and Review Act suspends the requirement for permits for vessel discharges and establishes national discharge standards enforced by the Coast Guard. Judicial review is also addressed in the Act. The Act establishes national discharge standards enforced by the Coast Guard. Judicial review of final regulations can be filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit within 120 days. Regulations subject to review under this section are not subject to judicial review in any civil or criminal proceeding for enforcement. The Vessel Discharge Evaluation and Review Act prohibits states from enforcing regulations on vessel discharges unless approved by the Administrator for greater environmental protection of state waters. The Vessel Discharge Evaluation and Review Act prohibits states from enforcing regulations on vessel discharges until adequate facilities are available and the prohibition does not burden commerce. Governors can request a review of regulations with new information for potential changes. The Vessel Discharge Evaluation and Review Act exempts certain discharges from permit requirements, including vessels of the Armed Forces, vessel sewage discharges, and discharges not subject to specific regulations. Additionally, no permit is needed for discharges incidental to the normal operation of vessels less than 79 feet in length engaged in commercial or recreational activities. The Vessel Discharge Evaluation and Review Act exempts certain discharges from permit requirements, including recreational vessels, aquatic nuisance species discharge, research-related discharges, and authorized discharges by an On-Scene Coordinator. The term "discharge incidental to the normal operation of a vessel" includes various types of discharges from marine systems and equipment, such as an aircraft carrier elevator or a catapult, or from a protective, preservative, or absorptive application to the hull of the vessel. This does not include discharges of rubbish, trash, garbage, or other materials overboard, air emissions from vessel propulsion systems, or discharges not covered by specific regulations. The Vessel Discharge Evaluation and Review Act establishes exclusive statutory authority for regulating vessel discharges by the Federal Government.
